Iss, 9th January 1943* 249 943 Dear Rumhold, A strange story is told me oy xne Red Cross of a soldier named Rene PIQUEMAL of the l6th R,A.D.A., General Staff, who was reported missing in the loss of the SIROCCO on May 30th 1940. He was presumed drowned by the International Red Cross after exhaustive enquiries. His father, however, now writes that he has obtained information from a source which he says is very sure 'I have learned that from England he was sent to India, somewhere near Calcutta, to be employed in a steel factory. I learnt once again that he left India on a Red Cross ship ’torpedo boat American WOOMING* which boat, after having touched at Cadiz, was never heard of again”. (I presume that he means that he left India on a Red Cross boat which carried the rescued crew of the torpedo boat WYOMING). This succession of events concerning a simple soldier seems to me extraordinary, but I cannot dismiss it,in view of the circumstances, without verification. If we could say that the son was not sent to India, and v/as not among the Wyoming crew, it would probably meet our purpose. Can you help me?. Yours sincerely, ft£Co. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 10; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between the Government of India, External Department, the Office for the High Commissioner for India, and the British Mission to the French National Committee, regarding a missing soldier named René Piquemal, who was said to be employed in a steel factory in India, but never found.
